levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying individual phonemes in simple CVC words using picture support and oral segmenting.
levels.example_task: Listen to the word 'cat'. Hold up one finger for each sound you hear. How many sounds are in 'cat'?
levels.example_response: Three sounds: /c/ /a/ /t/ (child holds up three fingers)
common_errors: Counting letters instead of sounds (saying 'cat' has three letters rather than identifying the phonemes)
Adding a schwa to consonant sounds, saying 'cuh-a-tuh' instead of /c/ /a/ /t/

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying phonemes in words containing digraphs and adjacent consonants.
levels.example_task: How many sounds are in the word 'ship'? Say each sound separately.
levels.example_response: Three sounds: /sh/ /i/ /p/
common_errors: Splitting the digraph and saying four sounds: /s/ /h/ /i/ /p/
Miscounting sounds in words with adjacent consonants (e.g., saying 'stop' has three sounds instead of four)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Accurately identifying all phonemes in words with digraphs, trigraphs and adjacent consonants without support.
levels.example_task: Say each sound in the word 'string'. How many phonemes does it have?
levels.example_response: Six phonemes: /s/ /t/ /r/ /i/ /ng/ — wait, five phonemes: /s/ /t/ /r/ /i/ /ng/
common_errors: Treating 'ng' as two separate sounds instead of one phoneme
Confusing the number of letters with the number of phonemes

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining that the same phoneme can be represented by different graphemes, and identifying phonemes in unfamiliar multisyllabic words.
levels.example_task: The word 'rain' and the word 'gate' both have the same vowel sound. What is the sound? How is it written differently in each word?
levels.example_response: Both have the /ay/ sound. In 'rain' it is written 'ai' and in 'gate' it is written 'a-e' (split digraph).
common_errors: Identifying the sound but not being able to name or describe the different grapheme representations
Thinking the sounds must be different because the spellings are different

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising single-letter graphemes and matching them to their most common phoneme.
levels.example_task: Point to the grapheme that makes the /s/ sound: s, m, t, a.
levels.example_response: Points to 's'.
common_errors: Confusing visually similar graphemes such as 'b' and 'd'
Selecting a grapheme by letter name rather than sound

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recognising common digraphs (sh, ch, th, ai, ee, oa) as single graphemes representing one phoneme.
levels.example_task: Circle the grapheme that makes one sound in the word 'chip': c-h-i-p.
levels.example_response: Circles 'ch'.
common_errors: Circling 'c' and 'h' separately instead of 'ch' as one grapheme
Not recognising that two letters can represent a single sound

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Identifying graphemes including digraphs, trigraphs and split digraphs in words, and knowing that one phoneme can have multiple grapheme spellings.
levels.example_task: Underline the graphemes in the word 'night'. How many graphemes are there?
levels.example_response: Three graphemes: n-igh-t.
common_errors: Splitting 'igh' into separate letters and counting five graphemes
Not recognising 'igh' as a trigraph representing one phoneme

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining that the same phoneme can be written with different graphemes and choosing between alternative spellings.
levels.example_task: Write three different ways to spell the /ee/ sound. Give a word example for each.
levels.example_response: 'ee' as in 'tree', 'ea' as in 'meat', 'e-e' as in 'theme'.
common_errors: Giving only one or two alternative spellings
Providing graphemes but not being able to think of real word examples

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Matching single-letter graphemes to their most common phoneme using flashcards or picture cues.
levels.example_task: I show you the letter 's'. What sound does it make?
common_errors: Saying the letter name 'ess' instead of the phoneme /s/
Adding a schwa: saying 'suh' instead of /s/

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Applying GPCs for common digraphs and beginning to recognise that some graphemes have more than one pronunciation.
levels.example_task: What sound does 'ow' make in the word 'cow'? What sound does 'ow' make in the word 'snow'?
levels.example_response: 'ow' in 'cow' makes /ow/ (as in ouch). 'ow' in 'snow' makes /oa/ (as in go).
common_errors: Applying only one pronunciation of 'ow' to both words
Not realising that the same grapheme can represent different phonemes

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Applying GPCs fluently for all taught graphemes including alternatives, using context to select the correct pronunciation.
levels.example_task: Read these words aloud: 'house', 'hour', 'hope'. What do you notice about the letter 'h'?
levels.example_response: In 'house' and 'hope', the 'h' makes the /h/ sound. In 'hour', the 'h' is silent.
common_errors: Pronouncing the 'h' in 'hour' because the GPC for 'h' is usually /h/
Not using the context of the whole word to determine pronunciation

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining why English has complex GPCs and identifying patterns in how graphemes represent different phonemes.
levels.example_task: The letter 'c' makes different sounds in 'cat' and 'city'. Can you explain when 'c' makes a /s/ sound?
levels.example_response: The letter 'c' makes a /s/ sound when it comes before 'e', 'i' or 'y', like in 'city', 'cent' and 'cycle'. Before 'a', 'o' or 'u' it makes a /k/ sound.
common_errors: Knowing the two sounds but not being able to state the rule about which vowels trigger which pronunciation
Thinking the rule is random rather than pattern-based

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Blending spoken phonemes into CVC words with adult modelling and picture support.
levels.example_task: I say the sounds /c/ /a/ /t/. Push them together to make a word. What word is it?
levels.example_response: Cat.
common_errors: Repeating the individual sounds without merging them into a word
Blending only the first two sounds and guessing the rest

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Blending phonemes in CCVC and CVCC words and words containing digraphs without picture support.
levels.example_task: Read this word by blending the sounds: 'frog'.
levels.example_response: Child sounds out /f/ /r/ /o/ /g/ and blends to say 'frog'.
common_errors: Omitting one consonant in the cluster, reading 'fog' instead of 'frog'
Blending too slowly and losing the whole word — saying each sound but unable to synthesise

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Blending phonemes fluently in words with adjacent consonants, digraphs and trigraphs to read unfamiliar words accurately.
levels.example_task: Read this word: 'thrush'.
levels.example_response: Child identifies 'thr' onset and 'ush' rime, blends to say 'thrush'.
common_errors: Splitting the trigraph 'thr' and producing an incorrect blend
Reading only the first syllable of longer words and guessing

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Blending fluently in multisyllabic words and self-correcting when the first blending attempt does not produce a recognisable word.
levels.example_task: Read this word: 'adventure'. If your first try doesn't sound like a real word, try again.
levels.example_response: Child segments into syllables 'ad-ven-ture', blends each syllable, then combines to say 'adventure'.
common_errors: Giving up after the first attempt rather than trying an alternative pronunciation
Blending the first syllable correctly but rushing or guessing the rest

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Segmenting spoken CVC words into individual phonemes using Elkonin boxes or finger counting.
levels.example_task: Say the word 'dog'. Push a counter into a box for each sound you hear.
levels.example_response: Child pushes three counters: /d/ /o/ /g/.
common_errors: Saying the word as a whole without breaking it into phonemes
Counting syllables instead of phonemes

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Segmenting words with adjacent consonants and digraphs into phonemes for spelling.
levels.example_task: Segment the word 'chest' into its sounds so you can spell it.
levels.example_response: /ch/ /e/ /s/ /t/ — four sounds.
common_errors: Splitting the digraph 'ch' into /c/ /h/, resulting in five sounds
Missing sounds in the consonant cluster at the end: writing 'chet' instead of 'chest'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Segmenting words accurately for spelling, including words with digraphs, trigraphs and adjacent consonants, choosing appropriate graphemes.
levels.example_task: Segment the word 'sprint' and write it.
levels.example_response: /s/ /p/ /r/ /i/ /n/ /t/ — writes 'sprint'.
common_errors: Omitting a consonant in the blend, writing 'spint' or 'srint'
Writing letters in the wrong order within the cluster

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Segmenting multisyllabic words and selecting the correct grapheme from known alternatives for each phoneme.
levels.example_task: Segment and spell the word 'rainbow'. Explain which grapheme you chose for the /ay/ sound and why.
levels.example_response: Writes 'rainbow'. 'I used 'ai' for the /ay/ sound because 'ai' usually goes in the middle of a word.'
common_errors: Choosing a plausible but incorrect grapheme (e.g., 'rane-bow')
Segmenting correctly but unable to explain the grapheme choice

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Decoding simple CVC words in a decodable text using known GPCs.
levels.example_task: Read this sentence from your reading book: 'The cat sat on a mat.'
levels.example_response: Child points to each word and decodes: 'The... cat... sat... on... a... mat.'
common_errors: Guessing 'cap' for 'cat' by looking only at the first letter
Relying on the picture to guess rather than decoding the graphemes

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Decoding words with digraphs and adjacent consonants in connected text, applying taught GPCs.
levels.example_task: Read this sentence: 'The frog jumped into the pond with a splash.'
levels.example_response: Child decodes each word, including 'frog', 'jumped', 'pond', 'splash', using phonic knowledge.
common_errors: Guessing 'jumped' as 'jump' without reading the suffix
Skipping 'splash' because it looks long, or guessing from the picture

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Decoding unfamiliar words accurately on first attempt in age-appropriate texts, self-correcting when needed.
levels.example_task: Read this passage aloud. When you come to a word you don't know, use your phonics to work it out.
levels.example_response: Child reads fluently, pausing to decode unfamiliar words such as 'scrambled' or 'frightened' using phonic strategies.
common_errors: Skipping unfamiliar words instead of attempting to decode them
Decoding accurately but too slowly to retain meaning of the sentence

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Decoding polysyllabic words by breaking them into syllables and applying phonic knowledge, including words not yet encountered.
levels.example_task: Read this word you haven't seen before: 'thunderstorm'. How did you work it out?
levels.example_response: 'Thunder-storm'. I split it into two parts: 'thun-der' and 'storm'. I know 'th' and 'or' graphemes.
common_errors: Attempting to decode the whole word in one pass without syllable segmenting
Correctly decoding each syllable but failing to combine them fluently

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising a small set of high-frequency decodable words instantly on flashcards.
levels.example_task: Read these words as quickly as you can: 'the', 'and', 'is', 'it', 'in'.
levels.example_response: Child reads all five words instantly without sounding out.
common_errors: Needing to sound out every word, indicating the words are not yet automatic
Confusing visually similar words like 'it' and 'is'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recognising Year 1 common exception words and high-frequency words automatically in context.
levels.example_task: Read this sentence without stopping to sound out: 'He said he was going to the house.'
levels.example_response: Child reads fluently, recognising 'said', 'was', 'going', 'house' automatically.
common_errors: Pausing to decode 'said' or 'was' each time, indicating these are not yet automatic
Reading known words automatically but slowing for every unfamiliar word

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading most age-appropriate words automatically, only needing to decode genuinely unfamiliar or rare words.
levels.example_task: Read this page from your reading book aloud. I will note which words you read automatically and which you need to decode.
levels.example_response: Child reads the page fluently with automatic recognition of most words, decoding only one or two unfamiliar words.
common_errors: Reading common words automatically but still decoding words that should be familiar by this stage
Reading automatically but inaccurately — recognising the shape of a word but reading a different word

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Reading with automatic recognition across a wide range of texts, including words from Year 2 common exception word list and beyond.
levels.example_task: Read this passage from an unfamiliar Year 3 book. Which words did you need to decode rather than recognise?
levels.example_response: Child reads with fluency and expression, identifying only specialist vocabulary that required decoding.
common_errors: Over-relying on automatic recognition and misreading words that look similar (e.g., reading 'through' as 'though')
Not noticing when automatic recognition produces the wrong word

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading a small set of common exception words with picture or context support.
levels.example_task: Read these words: 'the', 'I', 'no', 'go', 'to'.
levels.example_response: Child reads all five words correctly.
common_errors: Attempting to decode 'the' as /t/ /h/ /e/ rather than recognising it as a whole word
Confusing 'no' and 'on' due to letter reversal

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading and spelling Year 1 common exception words (e.g., said, come, some, one, were) with some accuracy.
levels.example_task: Write these words from memory: 'said', 'come', 'were', 'there'.
levels.example_response: Child writes 'said', 'come', 'were', 'there' correctly.
common_errors: Spelling 'said' as 'sed' using phonics rules
Writing 'wer' for 'were' or 'ther' for 'there'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading and spelling Year 1 and Year 2 common exception words accurately, including in dictated sentences.
levels.example_task: Write this sentence from dictation: 'They could not find their beautiful new clothes.'
levels.example_response: Child writes the sentence with 'could', 'their', 'beautiful', 'clothes' spelled correctly.
common_errors: Spelling 'beautiful' as 'butiful' or 'beutiful'
Confusing 'their' with 'there'

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Identifying the tricky parts of exception words and explaining why they cannot be fully decoded using phonics.
levels.example_task: Look at the word 'people'. Which part is tricky? Why can't you just sound it out?
levels.example_response: 'The 'eo' in the middle is the tricky part. If you sounded it out using phonics, you would say /p/ /ee/ /o/ /p/ /l/ /e/, which doesn't sound like 'people'. The 'eo' makes a /ee/ sound which is unusual.'
common_errors: Saying the whole word is tricky without pinpointing the specific irregular part
Not recognising that parts of exception words are decodable (e.g., the 'p' and 'l' in 'people')

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising common vowel digraphs (ai, ee, oa) with picture cue support and reading simple words containing them.
levels.example_task: Read these words: 'rain', 'tree', 'boat'.
levels.example_response: Child reads 'rain', 'tree', 'boat' correctly, recognising the digraphs.
common_errors: Sounding out each letter separately: /r/ /a/ /i/ /n/ instead of /r/ /ai/ /n/
Not recognising the digraph and producing a nonsense pronunciation

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading and spelling words with a range of vowel digraphs (ai, ee, oa, oo, ou, ow, oi, igh, ear, air, ure) in context.
levels.example_task: Sort these words by their vowel sound: 'moon', 'book', 'food', 'look', 'room', 'good'.
levels.example_response: Long /oo/: moon, food, room. Short /oo/: book, look, good.
common_errors: Not distinguishing between the two pronunciations of 'oo' (long as in 'moon' vs short as in 'book')
Applying one pronunciation of 'oo' to all words

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading and spelling words with vowel digraphs accurately, including choosing the correct digraph when multiple spellings exist for the same sound.
levels.example_task: Spell the word 'trainee'. Which vowel digraphs did you use?
levels.example_response: Writes 'trainee'. 'I used 'ai' for the /ay/ sound and 'ee' for the /ee/ sound.'
common_errors: Using an incorrect but plausible digraph (e.g., 'traynee')
Correctly identifying the sound but choosing the wrong grapheme representation

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining alternative spellings for the same vowel sound and identifying patterns in when each spelling is typically used.
levels.example_task: The /oa/ sound can be spelt 'oa', 'ow' or 'o-e'. Give an example word for each. Do you notice where each spelling usually appears in a word?
levels.example_response: 'oa' in 'coat' — usually in the middle. 'ow' in 'snow' — usually at the end. 'o-e' in 'home' — the 'e' goes at the end with a consonant between.
common_errors: Providing examples but not noticing the positional pattern
Confusing 'ow' for /oa/ (as in 'snow') with 'ow' for /ow/ (as in 'cow')

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising the most common consonant digraphs (sh, ch, th) and reading simple words containing them.
levels.example_task: Read these words: 'shop', 'chin', 'thin'.
levels.example_response: Child reads all three words correctly, producing the digraph sounds.
common_errors: Saying /s/ /h/ /o/ /p/ instead of /sh/ /o/ /p/
Confusing 'sh' and 'ch' sounds

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading and spelling words with a wider range of consonant digraphs (sh, ch, th, ng, wh, ck, ph) including in different positions within words.
levels.example_task: Write these words: 'ring', 'which', 'phone', 'thick'.
levels.example_response: Child writes 'ring', 'which', 'phone', 'thick' correctly.
common_errors: Writing 'fone' instead of 'phone' — not recognising 'ph' as /f/
Forgetting the silent 'w' in 'which' and writing 'wich'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using consonant digraphs accurately in reading and spelling, including distinguishing voiced and unvoiced 'th'.
levels.example_task: Read these words and sort them: does the 'th' sound the same in 'this' and 'think'?
levels.example_response: 'This' has a voiced /th/ (buzzy). 'Think' has an unvoiced /th/ (whispery). They are different sounds made by the same letters.
common_errors: Not hearing the difference between voiced and unvoiced 'th'
Pronouncing both as unvoiced /th/

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining rules about consonant digraph placement and recognising less common digraphs in unfamiliar words.
levels.example_task: Why do we use 'ck' in 'kick' but just 'k' in 'week'? Can you explain the pattern?
levels.example_response: 'ck' comes after a short vowel sound — kick, duck, neck. 'k' comes after a long vowel or consonant — week, milk, park.
common_errors: Knowing the rule implicitly but being unable to articulate it
Over-applying the 'ck' pattern to all words ending in /k/

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising the split digraph pattern in simple word pairs with adult support.
levels.example_task: Read these two words: 'cap' and 'cape'. What happens to the vowel sound when the 'e' is added?
levels.example_response: 'Cap' has a short /a/. 'Cape' has a long /ay/. The 'e' makes the vowel say its name.
common_errors: Reading 'cape' as 'cap-ee', sounding out the final 'e'
Not noticing that the vowel sound changes

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading and spelling words with all five split digraphs (a-e, e-e, i-e, o-e, u-e) with some accuracy.
levels.example_task: Read these words: 'make', 'theme', 'kite', 'hope', 'cube'.
levels.example_response: Child reads all five words correctly, applying the split digraph pattern.
common_errors: Forgetting the split digraph pattern for less common forms (e.g., 'u-e' in 'cube')
Applying the split digraph rule to words where it doesn't apply (e.g., reading 'have' with a long /a/)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using split digraphs accurately in both reading and spelling, including distinguishing words where the pattern does and does not apply.
levels.example_task: Spell these words: 'stripe', 'alone', 'complete'. Underline the split digraph in each.
levels.example_response: Writes 'stripe' (i-e), 'alone' (o-e), 'complete' (e-e) and underlines the split digraphs correctly.
common_errors: Omitting the final 'e' when spelling (e.g., writing 'strip' for 'stripe')
Underlining only the 'e' rather than both parts of the split digraph

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Identifying exception words that look like split digraph words but are not, and explaining why.
levels.example_task: Why doesn't the word 'have' follow the split digraph rule, even though it ends in 'e' after a consonant and vowel?
levels.example_response: 'Have' looks like it should have a long /a/ sound like 'cave', but it doesn't — the 'a' stays short. It's an exception word. Other exceptions include 'give', 'come' and 'love'.
common_errors: Assuming all words with the vowel-consonant-e pattern must follow the split digraph rule
Unable to think of other exceptions

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Clapping or tapping the beats in spoken words to identify the number of syllables.
levels.example_task: Clap the beats in these words: 'cat', 'rabbit', 'elephant'. How many claps for each?
levels.example_response: 'Cat' — 1 clap. 'Rabbit' — 2 claps. 'Elephant' — 3 claps.
common_errors: Clapping for each phoneme instead of each syllable
Miscounting syllables in words with adjacent vowels (e.g., 'lion' as one syllable)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Segmenting written words into syllables as a strategy for reading longer words.
levels.example_task: Break the word 'sunset' into syllables to help you read it.
levels.example_response: 'Sun-set' — two syllables.
common_errors: Splitting at the wrong point (e.g., 'su-nset')
Not recognising that each syllable must contain a vowel sound

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using syllable segmentation to read and spell multisyllabic words, understanding that every syllable has a vowel sound.
levels.example_task: Break these words into syllables: 'wonderful', 'yesterday', 'September'.
levels.example_response: 'Won-der-ful' (3), 'yes-ter-day' (3), 'Sep-tem-ber' (3).
common_errors: Not splitting at the correct syllable boundary (e.g., 'wond-er-ful')
Counting the final 'e' as a separate syllable when it is silent

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the rule that every syllable contains a vowel sound and using this to self-check syllable counting.
levels.example_task: A child says 'smiled' has two syllables. Are they right? How do you know?
levels.example_response: 'Smiled' has one syllable because the '-ed' doesn't add a new vowel sound — it just adds a /d/. Each syllable must have a vowel sound, and 'smiled' only has one: /ai/.
common_errors: Agreeing that 'smiled' has two syllables because of the '-ed' ending
Not understanding that the syllable rule relates to vowel sounds, not vowel letters

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading a familiar decodable text aloud with accurate word reading, though pace may be slow and word-by-word.
levels.example_task: Read this page from a book you have read before. Try to read each word correctly.
levels.example_response: Child reads each word accurately but reads word by word with even pauses between words.
common_errors: Reading in a robotic, word-by-word manner without any phrasing
Losing the meaning of the sentence because of slow decoding

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading familiar texts with some phrasing and beginning to attend to punctuation for expression.
levels.example_task: Read this page aloud. Remember to pause at full stops and change your voice for questions.
levels.example_response: Child reads in short phrases, pausing at full stops and raising intonation for questions.
common_errors: Pausing at full stops but not changing intonation for questions or exclamations
Reading in a monotone despite attempting to phrase

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading age-appropriate texts fluently with appropriate pace, expression and phrasing, responding to punctuation.
levels.example_task: Read this passage aloud with expression, as if you were telling the story to someone.
levels.example_response: Child reads with natural phrasing, appropriate pace, varied intonation for dialogue and exclamations, and pauses at commas and full stops.
common_errors: Reading fluently on familiar texts but losing fluency on unfamiliar material
Reading too fast, sacrificing expression for speed

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Reading unfamiliar age-appropriate texts with expression and fluency, using voice to convey meaning and character.
levels.example_task: Read this passage from a book you haven't seen before. Use different voices for the characters and show the mood of the story.
levels.example_response: Child reads with fluency and expression, using distinct voices for characters, adjusting pace for suspense, and conveying mood through tone.
common_errors: Using exaggerated voices that obscure the words rather than supporting meaning
Maintaining fluency on dialogue but losing expression on narrative sections
